p.seg: In the seventh year of Emperor Gaozu of Han
Prime Minister Xiao He had the Weiyang Palace built.
The main building was built on the side of the Dragonhead Mountain,
and the palace gate towers stood to the north.
The perimeter of Weiyang Place was in all 22 li, 90 bu, five chi (more than 9000 me].
The streets within had a togtal length of 70 li [29 km].
There were 43 halls built upon terraces:
32 in th outer palce
eleven in the inner palace.
In the palace there were thriteen bodies of water
and six hills,
including one lake and one hill in the rear part of the palace.
There were 95 small gtes in total.
The Wu Emperor had the Kunming Lake made.
He wanted to attack the Kunwu Yi [barbarians],
and to teach and practice naval warfare.
The late was also used for entertainment for the emperor and to raise fish.
The fish were given to the ancestrsal temples for sacrifices,
and any remaining were sold at the Chag'an market.
The lake measured forty li around.
In the Han system,
in the eigth monthstrong wine was offered in the ancestral temple.
They used wine fermented nine times, with the sacrificial animals.
The emperor officiated.
They made the wine at dawn on the first day of the year;
it was ready in the eighth month.
It was called strong wine,
or "nine-fermented,"
or "full-bodied wine".
When therre was flooding in the capital
they sacrificed to the nountains and rivers to stop the rain.
The prime minister and censors,and officials who received 2000 bushels of grain as salary, all prayed for the spirits to intervene.
It was the same for pryers to ask for rain.
The Son of Heaven's brushes
had handles inlaid with gems,
and the bristles were all from the hair of autumn hares
The official Lu Hu made them.
Their cases were made of various precious materials,
with sides decorated with jade bi and kingfisher feathers,
altogether worth a fortune.
Under the Han system,
the emperor's low table was jade.
In the winter a thick brocade caled "table-silk" was laid on top.
[table silk]
Elephant ivory was used for small braziers
which were decorated with flower patterns.
In the rear palace, there were also five-colloured decorated satins.
They used wine to grind ink
and jade inkstones
because these did not freeze.
In the summer, feather fans were set out.
The great nobles all used bamboo and wood for their low tables, and in the winter
[The great nobles all used bamboo and wood for their low tables,]
and in the winter these were also covered with fine felt for them to lean on.
They were not allowed to use silk brocade.
In the time of Emperor Wu,
a western domain presented him with a jiguang [a mythical beast, "lucky shining"] fur garment,
which could go into water without getting wet.
The emperor often wore this garment when he held court.
The Emperor Gaozu's concubine, Lady Qi, played the zither and the lute very well.
The em;peror often embraced Lady Qi, singing along to the strings.
When the music finished,
they would both be sobbing and tearful.
Lady Qi also danced very well, waving her sleeves and bending her waist.
She would sing the songs "Beyond the frontier," "Coming across the frontier," and "Hoping to go home;
the hundreds of serving women would all practice these.
In the rear palace, when they all sang together,
the sound would reach the heavens.
Lady Qi had rings made of god refined a hundred times,
so bright you could see the bones of her fingers.
The emperor did not like them
so she gave them to her servants mingyu, Yaoguang and others.
They each got four rings.
The Prince of Zhao, Ruyi [Lady Qi's son], was very young,
and could not yet have a tutor from outside.
Lady Qi had him taught by an old woman named Zhao, who had been the nurse of the King of the Zhao [Zhao Ao[.
She called his building the "Raising-Virtue Palace,"
but later it was changed to "Fish and Water-Plant Palace".
